messageBody:
On Fri, 19 Sep 2003 08:22:59 +0100, "Chris Dollin" <chris.dollin@...>
said:
>
> assertTrue( informative message, boolean )
>
> It is a deep shame that Java doesn't have method literals (aka lambdas,
> or Smalltalk blocks, or whatever) so that `informative message` could be
> a hairy expression that's not actually evaluated unless the test fails.

How about this? :)

public abstract class HairyExpression {
/**
* evaluates a hairy expression and returns a message
* based on the evaluation
*/
public abstract String evaluate();

public String toString() {
return evaluate();
}
}

assertTrue(
new HairyExpression () {
public String evaluate() {
...
}},
false);

Then extend the Assert capabilities of JUnit to use the toString() of the
object passed in if the assertion fails.

There are of course better ways of doing these things. I just wanted to
make the point that we can make the framework do anything we want. Is it
pretty? No. But if it's necessary who cares if it's pretty (he says
tongue-in-cheek)?

--
=jason
